page.title: 07St Mary's Church Whittlebury
page.content: Enter the churchyard by the lychgate. The tower and porch were built in the 13th century. High up on the tower is a Norman window and there are five bells within. The porch floor is constructed from up-ended slates. The oldest part of the church is the west arch which is pointed, with two bands of leafy ornament. The altar pictures depicting the Annunciation, Presentation and Crucifixion are gold and mosaic. Adjacent to the choir stalls is the vicar's seat with carvings of dragons on its arms. The pulpit was carved in the Middle Ages. There is an old oak chest about 2.5 metres long. The vicar also serves Paulerspury and Wicken. The church has a choir of 13 and the Sunday School has 12 pupils who attend every fortnight.
